commentBody: Good theme. Moderate 20-minure solve
agreed, it was a fun one, with a faster-than-usual solve for me. I first entered "I need some space" for the revealer at 115A. same number of letters!

I really like how the “me” phrases have a completely different sound than the “u” phrases. That made them more fun to figure out than other letter substitutions.
(“A losing rattle” or “seize the hay” etc)

I can’t resist the MERGE to find some other example - but if I don’t return, you’ll know why.

Yesterday's puzzle was such a buzzkill for me that I began to consider if it's time for me to drop the crossword subscription (with print edition -- now about 40 years).  But this puzzle was enough fun that I'll hold off for a while.  

Thanks for the puzzle.
Satisfying.
Not done yet, but I just want to say that "Caesar's addressing" is fantastic

Cautioned myself to LEAVEIIN the wrong letters, thereby aVOIDING MYLOSS.  IMHO, this was a fine Sunday solve.  Engaging and relaxing and funny.

Welcome to the NY Times, Andrew Colin Kirk.  I'm sure we'll see you again.
Nice puzzle, plenty of crunch. I stared at 77 ACROSS for the longest time, and had to run through the alphabet to arrive at SEXILE. Oh my Lord I'm dense sometimes.
I loved so many of the clues. 20A still has me rolling on the floor.

For me it was one of the easier Sundays that I've solved in quite some time. Having read the title (Where'd you go), I noticed about half way through that there were no "U"s in the puzzle whatsoever. When I got to the revealer (which had the only U), it was evident what the theme was. This allowed me to start filling in the themers that I had been unable to do up to that point. 

It was a very creative idea, and a fun solve. Today I learned that SEXILE was a thing. I've been a professor for 40 years and never heard of it. I guess that makes me a lifelong learner. Congratulations to the constructor, and wishing you the best for the future after your sudden loss of livelihood.

My streak is now 1!!!!!

I really thought I was going to flop two days in a row.  You'd think, given that I've been sexiled for some time now, I would have figured that one out.   But no.

Also took me forever to get ANTITAX because when I run the alphabet in my head, I almost always daydream at "X".

Good puzzle, and I thought the theme was hilarious.

But I'm a little confused around MENDERLINES.  I see how it works for the questions in the clue, but I'm not sure "underlines" means anything in relation to the clue.

Can anyone shed some light?
Very cute. Easy for Sunday. My fastest yet. Thanks for a good puzzle!!

Breakup line for an arborist: "It's not yew, it's me."

("But we were going to put down roots together!"
"I'm sorry, I just have to branch out.")
Almost as good as a USA Today puzzle
This is a charming puzzle.  I especially appreciate the fact that the constructor keeps trivia and obscure facts to a minimum.

Don’t know if Andrew Colin Kirk is a regular reader of Wordplay, but some time last fall I learned from the column the “solving jingle” is called “The San Jose Strut” . Just one of those bits of trivia I have cluttering up the mind. Fun puzzle with a cleverly executed theme.
Came in at about half my Sunday average….  Pretty straightforward, didn’t stop to figure out the theme but did notice some odd answers so I guess that’s where the theme showed up..,  :-)
Wonderful puzzle, perfect for a Sunday. I really enjoyed it.

Quite a fun Sunday, and it solved a bit faster than my usual. Filled in most of the themers, and then when I got the revealer, which became obvious after just a few letters, I got the rest done.

About SEXILE, I'm sure the practice has been around for decades, if not centuries, whether the term has been or not. 

Very nice debut, Andy, and hope to see more of your puzzles here.
Great debut, Andrew!  A very fun and clever puzzle, with a good laugh out loud at 20-Across (SMELLIER). Glad you didn’t give up!

"It had to be you
It had to be you
I wandered around, and I finally found
The somebody who
Could make me be true
And could make me be blue
And even be glad
Just to be sad - thinking of you
Some others I've seen
Might never be mean
Might never be cross, or try to be boss
But they wouldn't do
For nobody else gave me a thrill
With all your faults, I love you still
It had to be you
Wonderful you
It had to be you"

Thanks for the workout and lovely puzzle.
Just learned about sextile. - there's always something new to add to my crossword word collection.

Be well & enjoy!
Thanks for this wonderful puzzle, Andrew Colin Kirk! A fresh, fun, very clever debut.  I’m sure it was much harder to construct than to solve. (Aren’t they all?)
I think the concept and construction are very good, and there’s admirably small amounts of crosswordese and trivia. Some of the thematic cluing is tortured.

I did it!

I thought the theme answers were clever, but not pun-difficult (puns make me sigh). 

Finally, Leslie ODOM Jr?  Am still not over the majesty and tragedy of his Aaron Burr.
good crossword puzzle to help me through a breakup... strong fill/cluing and the theme was quite clever

Now that I understand the new word SEXILE, I'm wondering....

Should I be worried that sometimes when I head to bed my wife has put a tie on our bedroom door.  I never really thought about it before, but now....
Definitely more enjoyable than yesterday. Still laughing at MEN SOLVED MYSTERIES, that was fantastic.

Has anyone else lost all their stats?

I send a message to the NYT already, but I was wondering if anyone else is experiencing this weird sense of abandonment?

I keep forgetting to read the title, but the revealer was perfect in telling me what I needed to know. My last to fall was the "X" of SEXILE though I didn't have to run the whole alphabet (phew!) for the penny to drop. [Ambrosia salad ingredient] distracted me, remembering the band Ambrosia and going to YouTube to find them. This is them live: https://youtu.be/0QIWtY7gzvA?si=S2w1-ruvVqqZ71vM And this is my favorite of theirs: https://youtu.be/A1jeVdUo1-I?si=r9Yv2C0g37Gc0X9D Thank you, Andrew, for a very tight, interesting, and creative puzzle that was a joy to solve. The hard work you put into it is very much appreciated! Best of luck to you and your husband on your move to Denver and the new chapter that's beginning in your life. May the door that closed be only a catalyst for a wonderful new door that's opening. All my best to you.
Fun puzzle. Oddly OUTS also works as a word after read and cash
AIDA was the OPERA for the Metropolitan Opera New Year's Eve Gala. I had the privilege of seeing it on December 31st, and Angel Blue was a fantastic lead!
My fastest Sunday yet! Got the theme early, definitely boosted my weekend 🥰

Really loved [Crude cavity].

For the emus, it's not emu, it's palindromic em-me

I generally solve late week puzzles by building off the first answer I get (as opposed to doing all crosses, then downs). 

So I got RESIST THE MERGE very early. And then when I got the second theme answer.   guessed that the revealer was gonna be exactly what it was.  I’m kinda proud of myself. 

I kept thinking about Thursdays kerfuffle regarding finishing a puzzle without seeing the trick.  Can’t that be said about this one as well?  I hope I don’t read a bunch of comments complaining about this. 

My only gripe is that I wish the calling was harder. This seemed like a relatively easy? Sunday.  For my ego, I hope others don’t agree

Well, 1A was a gimme :D

 - Alexis in Perth
Aperol and fogs were aperil and figs until I finally checked the puzzle to finish.
That was fun.

There was nothing wrong with the puzzle, really, but I did not personally enjoy it much. It was OK, but I just don't see what's especially cool about butchering common phrases for the sake of dad-joke-level wordplay. The one positive for me would be the fact for once I was not confused by a phonetic element in the revealer. The revealer itself was a gimme, considering I knew the phrase, and the revealer's clue implied substituting something for something else.

Some of the clues were quite nice though: "Higher in rank" solving to SMELLIER made me smile, even if the theme did not.

I've never had a roommate so SXEILE (typo for prudish "moderation" which usually does not allow us to use grown up words because... /Shrugs in European) was new and interesting.

I needed a lot of lookups today: as per usual I did not know most of the proper nouns, some of the abbreviations, etc.

[What Babe Ruth meant, when, at bat, in the 1932 World Series, he famously pointed to the center field bleachers]










THE HOMER IS NIGH

Strands Thread:

Strands #385
“In stitches”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.
Congratulations, Andrew. Most enjoyable. And 36A a gem.

The clever wordplay in the themers gave me an early morning smile today. I was solving fairly smoothly and picked up steam when I got to the revealer, but FINESTHOMER took me some time to work out, especially as I couldn’t immediately come up with ENBY or GOGO boots. MENSOLVEDMYSTERIES particularly tickled my fancy.  In the non-theme department. I also liked SMELLIER for higher in rank and SEXILE.

Seeing Peter OTOOLE, the king of historical drama, who made Henry II come to life on the big screen twice (among many other titanic roles), reminded me that tonight is the premier of the sequel to Wolf Hall on PBS.  Mark Rylance’s portrayal of Thomas Cromwell in Wolf Hall was positively O’Toole(Ian) and did justice to Hilary Mantel’s brilliant  trilogy.  Hopefully the sequel is as good.
Wow!  Excellent debut, Andrew.  I loved the theme, and [Higher in rank?] solving to SMELLIER   is one of my all-time favorites clues.

Nice puzzle, but a good long workout for me. Took me a while to finally catch on and then... my fading brain power. Even after I got it I had to stop and ponder on each of the theme answers to remember exactly what was going on. Ah, well. No big deal. 

A couple of oddly similar puzzle finds today. I'll put those in a reply. 

...

I like how with a dictionary and gumption, rather than a computer and code, 
Andrew came up with these theme answers.

I like seeing reveals like IT’S NOT YOU, IT’S ME, that are so perfect for crosswords, and I love the puzzle-makers that find them and run with them – driven by and wishing to share the delight of wordplay.

I find inspiring the backstory of Andrew, whose dream of having a puzzle in the Times met with 10 rejections, yet he forged on. His reward on the 11th is ours as well.

It was fun to run across some serendipities in the grid: Two rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilaps (LOOPS, ELIOT), and the answer consisting of Andrew’s initials albeit out of order (AKC).

All this adding up to a feel-good experience, and feel-good is real good, no?  Thank you so much for this, Andrew, and congratulations on your NYT debut!

Lots of interesting clues but some obscure for me.

Are these phrases used in the US - or just for the crossword?
RESIST THE MERGE 
NAILED THE DIS MOMENT?

FINEST HOMER - what is that? A home run thing?
EDT? Can't see connection to Somerset.
OTTO was a mystery until I realised ....
I wonder if the use of auto is from German influence?

What a de-beaut!

Talk about wordplay!
Andrew nailed this one.

Even knowing the theme,
I loved that I had to squinch my nose
and peel apart a couple themers to
see the missing U.

By middle school I had learned
I had a knack for putting words together.

I needed to break up with a boy (Dave)
and did it the classy way-
in a note that my friend 
gave to his friend who
then gave it to poor Dave.

When my friend needed to do the same to
poor Chuck, she asked if I could help.

I just re-wrote the note,
she copied it,
and voila!

That ridiculous note broke up with at *least*
30 kids in 2 years. 
It was called The Note.
And I charged one pack of
Reese’s Peanut Butter cups.

Prolly should have seen 
my future as a copywriter right then…

Loved the puzzle.
Happy Sunday all!
This one was fun. I had the same experience as Caitlin, where I got the revealer before any of the clues, but still had a wild ride figuring them out.

"Unfortunately, he was laid off recently ... "

Is this a euphemism for "Fell victim to Trump's purge"?

Fun puzzle today.

I saw the title and immediately knew to expect some kind of omission or replacement for the letter U, so that was helpful. I still didn't see that every themer replaced U with ME, and not just some random replacement, until the end. Very clever theme.

What held me up the most? The exact thing I thought would be a problem: my chronic inability to remember if LASIK has an I or an E.

Thanks!
A very enjoyable puzzle.  Liked seeing my home province (Newfoundland) make it's way into it.  TERRA Nova is a beautiful park and would encourage anyone bitten by the travel bug to take it in.

An enjoyable Sunday puzzle!
Some clues made me smile, some made me wince, a few had me confused for a while... but it always kept me entertained.

I'm grateful for the distraction from what has become a very painful week.

To our constructor:

I’m not aware of who all in the NYTGames staff looked at your first 10 submissions, but was this eleventh one a puzzle Deb met?

Fun. “Finest Homer” is going into my vocabulary to confuse people. I liked how “ET TU”  as the only U made it clear that really, it was “you” after all.
I lose again.

Thanks for a fun one, Andrew! And as a DC resident, I’m sorry you lost your job. So many people in this area have been fired and it’s really taking a toll on this community at every level. And when folks say “call your representatives to voice your concerns!” but DC does not have voting representation in Congress, well, it stings. Good luck in Denver and enjoy being able to call your voting representatives!
Very clever and fun. Any tie-in to Seinfeld makes me smile. Congrats to a fellow Kansan.
Very cool!
huge fan of MEN SOLVED MYSTERIES, might be top 10 for me. truly tickled. great puzzle!

For me, the photo accompanying the column gives off an odd vibe.  The uncomfortable looks suggest a brother and sister who happened to go out for dinner, forgetting it was Valentines Day, only to be sprayed with pheromones. 

Awkward!!
This was fun.  Figured out the trick very early.  I was stuck on the SW corner at the end.  Not sure why.  Thanks!
A great debut showing some genuine talent for this crossword dodge.  Well done.

I thomeght the pmezzle was smeperb.  Fomer stars.

How abomet yome?
Solid Sunday. The theme line cracked me up. Glad I left it to the last. Bravo, Andrew!

Clever theme and cute thematic entries. The revealer seems perfect.

A gentle Sunday puzzle, and I finished in about 35 minutes. PANOPLY is great *word*. DEGERM isn't. 107A
"Turns inside out" signals some confusion between inversion and eversion, but likely only a mathematician would notice. "Crude cavity" for OILWELL was devilish, and paired nicely with the nearby (in the grid) ENID, Oklahoma.

Quite a nice debut. Congratulations to the constructor!

Stop trolling botanists:
They’re petioles, not stems.
:)

What a fun solve, and congratulations to Andrew! The column and comments have me crying over here. Seeing so much support for the constructor inspired my first-ever comment. Denver is a lovely city, my dude! Excited for your future puzzles. 

Resumed my streak with this one after my KITE got stuck in a tree yesterday ;)
20A was a laugh-out-loud moment. Congratulations on the debut, and best of luck in Denver!

Getting the trick was fairly instantaneous, but some of the Other Entries were bears!  I've never hears of APEROL, and then 77A held me up (X was the last letter into the grid.  I kept thinkin of SENILE...cough cough)

Had never heard of the comedic take-off on "The Scarlet Letter," but it sounds like fun!  LOL

Very STUCk on today's Spelling Bee--an unfamiliar position to be in.  I usually get to Genius + in a twinkling.  
My star, apparently, is fading.
And here I thought I had a great answer for 20A: STINKIER. Alas.

It was an easy one, but I had a smile on my face the whole time I was solving.  That does not happen too often.  Thanks Andrew for persevering and bringing us this lovely puzzle.  Hope that there are more soon.

Straightforward Sunday, crunchy enough to keep me guessing, but not impenetrable. A good workout, with a fun theme.

One query; can anyone explain 83D? I’m assuming it’s my county Mr Kirk refers to, but I don’t recognise EDT. It’s BST British Summer Time, before we fall back to GMT Greenwich Mean Time. Or have I got the wrong end of the stick and it’s not about time/Somerset as I understand it? Totes confused, as the young ones say.

A couple of days ago I mentioned my son was stuck in Bangkok after the Heathrow fire cancelled all incoming and outgoing flights. He finally arrived back in Blighty literally 15 minutes ago; the original cancelled flight took off 24 hours late, only to turn back 4 hours later after a medical emergency on board. Should have been home Friday night!
MENDERLINES?, SEXILE, APEROL

Worked this whole puzzle from top left to bottom right without grokking the theme until I got to the revealer. About 2 min. off a Sunday PB. 
Never knew SEXILE - MY LOSS, as I'm pretty sure I'll never need it!!

Took me forever, mostly because of sleepiness. The theme was super fun, though! (Once I woke up.) I automatically love any puzzle that mentions Sailor Moon.

I had ATM instead of AIR for way too long, considering how many times I've had to fill my front-left tire this winter. Why is it always that tire? It's one of life's [U]NSOLVED MYSTERIES.
Great puzzle! I loved the revealer, which did help me deduce the theme. Very clever, and nearly a new PB for me, at just under 25 minutes. It was also in my wheelhouse; no lookups or doubts!

Luckily SEXILE was easily inferred because I hadn't heard that one before. It made me laugh. Actually, the whole puzzle made me laugh. It was a romp!
I always wonder what goes into a puzzle so clever, and now I know how many attempts might be needed. Seems the eleventh time is the charm! Thanks for sticking with it, Andrew. Surely more will follow in rapid fashion.

Hi everyone,

Just wanted to say thank you for all of the kind words about this puzzle and well-wishes for my family’s move. Not every puzzle is for everyone, but I am delighted that so many of you enjoyed it. The crossword community (constructors, editors and solvers alike) is one of the most supportive and wholesome I’ve encountered on the internet, and I hope to have more puzzles for you all soon! Thanks for solving and reading this long comment.

Andy

PS Sorry about DEGERM. That space was originally occupied by the Toronto Raptors’ Brandon INGRAM but was reworked as part of a proper nouns purge. It was MY LOSS. 😜

After the “too easy” “too hard” quibbles this week, I found this one just right. 

As seems to be my wont, I came up with a clever but wrong answer that I stuck with (arm muscle informally, three letters = “gun,” HEH heh…not) despite having to change PERTH to accommodate it. 🙄 

OPERA and egypt both have five letters and something to do with AIDA… I astound myself sometimes, and enjoy the denouMEnt when I figure out my error. 

Thank goodness I gave a dinner party this weekend and a pretty bottle of APEROL caught my eye in the liquor store. I vaguely remembered an association with cough syrup so left it on the shelf, but it open that part of the grid nicely. 

Very clever, well-executed theme. I’m sure I’ll enjoy more from Andy.
I unfortunately fell asleep while doing this so my time was about 4 hours 20 minutes. LOL, but I loved the theme, super clever! I am still bad at Sundays though 😬
It's rare that a crossword makes me laugh out loud, but that was the case today when the theme fell into place. Great puzzle!

This was a fun one, an especially good one to work out the theme on my own, and I had a big laugh when I got to FINESTHOMER and realized the wordplay wasn't necessarily at the start of a word. Just good times all around, and a great debut puzzle.

The puzzle's theme brought to mind a story from the 1980's.

I worked with a lovely student teacher who had been dating her fellow for a long time.  She was expecting an engagement ring.
One evening she got a call from her beloved and was asked to meet him for coffee at the local diner. It was there that he broke up with her with the words,

"There are no sparks in our relationship."
"You want sparks?"
She then poured her cup of hot coffee into his lap.

They were escorted out of the diner and told never to return.

Coda-She didn't become a teacher. She moved to Florida and married a pharmacist.

It said I finished in 59:50, with Autocheck on! But everything went much faster when I came back to it this morning. I was only half done when I had to quit last night.

There was a lot I didn't know, but I think only five answers were completely unknown to me: 77A, 113A, 119A, 51D, and 94D. Mostly I sort of knew the answers even though it took crosses and surprise guesses to get some of them. I had never associated port wine with any country. A real surprise was 11D. It felt like DEGERM had to be a made-up word for the puzzle, but I know that isn't allowed.

I enjoyed this puzzle well enough, and it capped off a week of puzzles that were relatively easy for me, all coming in below average, Thursday close to a personal best. The theme of this puzzle, though, is what I want to comment on, because it is coincidental to my having read over the last few days the book It's Not Me It's You by John Kim and Vanessa Bennett, both relationship therapists and in a romantic relationship with each other. I'd like to recommend the book to anyone looking for relationship insight. I am always seeking such insight in my quest to blend better with humans. https://www.harperlibrarybookclub.com/9780063206311/its-not-me-its-you/
Did it bother anyone else that not all of the theme entries worked both ways with the clue? It seems to me that the theme relies on that element to work.

This was so much fun and a great theme!

The SW corner had me stumped for a while. I had to resort to checking today's column to get 121A, but the rest fell into place after that.

77A was a new term to me, but then again, my college dorm was all single rooms, so I never had a roommate to temporarily banish. 😄

Thanks, Mr. Kirk for a a thoroughly enjoyable Sunday!
Fun theme, had a good laugh at NAILEDTHEDISMOMENT even though I got hung up in the SW corner at the end for a minute because I put LANDED instead of NAILED.  Bravo!
DEGERM, by the way, has a real existence, but the attested usage in the OED relates to the removal of wheat germ from the kernel, sometimes by a machine fabulously known as a "degerminator".

Really enjoyed this one, great theme!Congrats to the constructor! I liked "crude cavity" and "higher in rank".  I tried something different today... instead of looking things up, I filled in some entries with my best guess, and seeing the wrong letters in there made me realize what the correct answer was. Towards the end, I only looked up one word (wheat capital), but that's it! I came so close to nailing the dismount!

Late puzzle find. Kind of unusual - a Sunday from February 27, 2005 by Mike Torch with the title "In pairs." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Works off and on as a hospital resident?" INTERNSINTURNS "Breathe during an ice storm?" INHALEINHAIL And some other theme answers: INCISESINSIZES INROADSINRHODES INQUIREINCHOIR INSIDERINCIDER And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/27/2005&g=100&d=A ...
An amazing puzzle - loved the theme and the entire solve

Fairly brutal, but I guess that's expected. I made tons of mistakes that stretched it out, I originally had mr h solved mysteries, then duo solved mysteries before finally getting men.

It's not you it's me was one of my first solves and as clever as it is, I was not since it didn't help me solve a single other answer as a clue. I thought it was a cadence clue, and so originally it's elementary for Holmes and Watson was my thought, it's not you it's me, it's elementary are phonetically similar.

Final time two and a half grueling hours and I made breakfast in between.
Just a recurring request to  posters to put the Across or Down Clue # in your comment to make it easier for all of us to know what you are referring to. Thanks.

Things came together pretty quickly, but then I got stumped on Common conjunctions, due to my insistence that a Powerful engine is a Honda VTEC, and not a VTEN (an uncommon engine layout in the automotive world).

I really enjoyed solving this puzzle and it also warms my heart reading about the constructors journey to getting a crossword published. Today’s puzzle was the perfect combination of all of the things that make crosswords so fun and addictive: a great theme, some funny plays on words, and plenty of those delicious “aha!” moments that urge (or is it MERGE) you forward.
Thank you for an enjoyable Smenday crossword that I can actually finish.

Fun and faster than average for me. I plugged in the revealer right away when all the theme answers and revealer were highlighted on my phone app. I was tickled that I had the right line, which I suppose was made more famous by George Costanza! 

Also tickled with the cute theme answers! Favorite was MENSOLVEMYSTERIES. Ha! But they were all good!

As many have commented, loved 20 across -  SMELLIER, and lots of other smiles throughout, which I'm particularly grateful for as it's been a difficult past week. I'm so appreciative of today's puzzle and this whole last week of puzzles, which I thought to be very fine and lovely diversions!

On my personal journey to increase my crossword ABS and TRI muscles, I notice myself increasingly finding little typos or other little errors, like not realizing I'm in the wrong square when I enter a letter meant elsewhere, while I'm solving the puzzle. So, now I'm more consistently getting immediate happy/dunce's music without having to dig through all my answers to find a little silly error. I'm especially pleased when this happens on a Sunday, because I'm typically solving on my phone, and the big grid can be hard in the app. 

Anyhow, I really enjoyed it and congratulate Andrew on a debut in which he really NAILEDTHEDISMOMENT!
This was a lot of fun, sometimes I roll my eyes at the wordplay bits but the me->u was perfectly clever.
Well done ACK - this made me smile

This was a fun puzzle.  I learned how old I am though…77 across was completely new to me; it was the last word/letter of the puzzle for me and I laughed out loud sitting by myself in my living room. Perfect!

Caitlin -- To pick a nit, "MENDERS LINES" in your column should be "MENDER LINES."

Great theme and excellent construction!

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
NG puzzle and solving help. I still have no idea about the right side, 2/3rds of the way down
Great puzzle! Check out an annotated version - www.thesundayglossword.com
I loved this theme - just too fun!  It’s so simple and clever and rewarding for the solver. More like this please!
READ ONLY ???
Puzzles like this leave me in awe of creators. The creativity and construction is a true wonder. Thoroughly enjoyed this solve and marveled at all the themed answers.

If it wasn’t intentional for this puzzle to be published on the exact day of the 25th Anniversary of the Broadway debut of my favorite musical, AIDA (the Sir Elton John/Sir Tim Rice one), I’m going to pretend that it was because it was clearly…Written in the Stars.

Super fun Sunday puzzle

Bit of a sidebar, but I made a delicious FARRO with mushrooms dish for lunch today (entirely coincidentally, a recipe I got from the NYT Cooking section)! Delicious!

(Thanks for a great puzzle!)
Any quibbles are forgotten and forgiven after solving FINEST HOMER. So good.

@Steven M. 

I find that stunningly fast.  I was almost four times slower.  Most of it was in the squares on near the eastern boundary, including SEXILE, PLANE, DONICELY, and ANTITAX.

@Steven M. 

With lookups of the trivia, filling the grid took me 27 minutes. No idea what that means.

@Steven M. 

While your solve time is certainly impressive, I’m actually glad that I can’t match it. I enjoyed the hour that I spent with this puzzle, and I think I’d be disappointed if it were over much sooner.

@Steven M.
Interesting you could solve so fast without at least one typo.  See what I mean?

@Heidi 

When you get fast enough that spending an hour on a Sunday puzzle feels like sitting in rush hour traffic, you can spend an hour or more participating in the comments.

The time you spend with the puzzle is as much as you want it to be, and getting faster (as long as you're not rushing) is called progress.

Not to brag, but I don't find 20 minutes "stunningly fast", as Francis calls it.  It's just a matter of your perspective.

@LBG 

How do you know he didn't have at least one typo he had to go back and find, and still finished within 20 minutes?  (Although your point is well taken.)

@Steve L Indeed. But in this case no typos. Had pubGAMES in there until the bitter end and couldn't figure out FRAY until I got FREEWIFI which in turn I needed COWBOY for and couldn't get in turn until I corrected it to BARGAMES

@Steve L 
Look at his post.

@LBG 

Good one!

Here’s what I got; they don’t really work:

A foment of wisdom 
Smelly your reputation 
Your resmelts may vary

Conclude: Andrew found the good ones!

Cat Lady Margaret,

Better than mine. After hours of concerted effort, all I came up with was:

UH.
Which is just MEH.

@pollyq Yes, I found yesterday's a bit upsetting too. Thought I must just be getting old and out of touch, maybe will have to lay off a bit. But today's renewed my faith in the NYT crossword. A sigh of relief! It was really enjoyable.
Me 2

@Jon Hallander 

I'm really impressed that you can type this comment while rolling on the floor! 

You must have a real TALENT!!  

😂

I jest, I found it really funny too!! My first couple looks at it I kind of home in on the question mark and as soon as I got it I laughed out loud!
@Andrew Oh, I didn't catch there were no other U's. Very clever.

Francis,

Those are lines a mender* would say.

*local tailor shop or handy friend
Or did I misunderstand your question?

@Barry Ancona

Francis,

I think the misread was on me.

@Francis I don't think the u-version is relevant to the clue or the answer (except for sharing most of the letters). For any of them, not just menderlines. The theme entries take a known word or phrase, replace "u" with "me", and then the clue is a possible description or example; the original is irrelevant.

Isabeau,

We agree the original is not needed to solve the themers, but in most of them, the well known "u" phrase is close in meaning to the "me" phrase.

Men solved mysteries and unsolved mysteries (36A) are close. Voter fraud and voter framed (86A) are close. Underlines and mender lines (47A) are not close.

@Barry Ancona They're close because they share all but two letters.  What's similar about an unsolved mystery and a solved mystery? The 'mystery' part.  The voter ones share 'voter' -- I suppose you could argue framing someone for a crime and committing fraud are both crimes, but unless you're being framed for fraud, there's no closer connection.

Underlines and mender lines are both lines.

The Sunday *fill* clues are normally in the Tuesday-Wednesday difficulty range; the theme and the theme clues are another matter.

Today, with a relatively simple theme, the puzzle should seem easy to most solvers. With a more convoluted theme, the easy fill clues may give less advanced solvers a foothold.

@Xword Junkie I thought there would be some objection to INVERTS for [Turns inside out]. It's a perfectly reasonable usage in medical terminology: https://www.msdmanuals.com/professional/gynecology-and-obstetrics/intrapartum-complications/uterine-inversion so fair enough, though perhaps obscure for most solvers.
@Xword Junkie I didn't mention "degerm" in my comment, since it just fell right in, but it did give me pause.

@Oikofuge "Uterine eversion" appears quite frequently. My *guess* is that "eversion" was the original usage even in this context. Here's a link to a 1915 mention of uterine eversion (in cows): https://doi.org/10.1016/S0372-5545(17)57184-9

@Xword Junkie I'll see your 1915 "eversion", and raise you an 1886 "inversion" ;-) https://wellcomecollection.org/works/x6tee2s6/items "Eversion" is also in use, certainly. I was just remarking that, in medical English, if you say that you've "inverted" a hollow structure, you'll be understood to have turned it inside out, rather than upside down, and that's been so for a long time. (On the other hand, if you invert an ankle joint, you've rotated the sole of the foot inwards; as opposed to eversion, in which the sole is tilted outwards.)

Here we go. In the medical sense of "turn inside out", the OED's first citation for "eversion" is from 1567 https://www.oed.com/dictionary/eversion_n And for "inversion" is 1565 https://www.oed.com/dictionary/inversion_n

@Oikofuge Thanks for pursuing this. So both words have been used medically for almost 500 years. 

In mathematics, we invert fractions, for example. And occasionally a graduate student politely says “Professor, do you realize your shirt is everted?” See also “sphere eversion”.

Marty,

None of the "u" entries *work* with the clues, nor are they supposed to do so. The "u" entries are common expressions; the "me" answers respond to the clues. Whether the "u" versions have anything at all to do with the clues varies from themer to themer (as discussed here yesterday), but that's an aesthetic matter, not a solving issue.
